Posts.Title: Ki-67 score vs. Oncotype neugirl Jewel259

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2013 06:39AM riverhorse wrote: Dear neugirl. I think you are looking for answers and certainty that just don't exist. I had an Oncotype. Score of 25, no LVI. And a low mitotic score of 1. When I decided against chemo my onc agreed but added "it's a crapshoot". Not a very comforting response but true. We all face the same awful situation. Regardless of grade or stage there is just no way to be sure about a breast cancer treatment or prognosis. Like many others I made my decision, continue to worry a bit about whether it was the right one, and moved on. Hope you are able to take all the information you have and make a decision that works for you. Sue

Posts.Content: May 23, 2014 11:55AM riverhorse wrote: hi.  Although I am not (yet) stage 4 I thought I would share this info I learned from a doc at MDA where I went with a stage IV friend with liver mets so she could get a second opinion before staring treatment. I asked about the potential change from ER+ to TN with the new tumor.  He said that as the initial tumor was ER+  a new TN tumor was not the same as one that started out TN.  In other words the new TN was actually the surviving ER-  cancer cells from the original tumor and thus less aggressive than a tumor that started TN in the breast.   You may want to verify this with your onc, but I thought this an important distinction.
Posts.Title: ER+/PR+ in bones, TN in new liver mets: Treatments? DragonGirl GrammyR

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 06:36AM riverhorse wrote: Most people connect through the small stuff.  While there is no way for those of us who are not stage 4 to comprehend what our loved ones are experiencing, our "small stuff" is a way to talk about life.  I think we realize that it is small, but we don't know how to eliminate everything from conversation except things important to our stage 4 loved ones.  We want our stage 4 loved ones to be part of our lives too -- and for us life is mostly "small stuff."
Posts.Title: Don't Sweet the Small Stuff Fitztwins Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 03:00AM - edited Jul 13, 2010 03:10AM by riverhorse Dear Nanalinda  I admire your courage. Of course you are right, the patient cannot "beat" the "foe".  But if you up front do not expect "victory" you certainly relieve your doctors of a lot of responsibility.  No matter how brave a warrior my daughter may turn out to be, her survival will depend on the medical profession, advances in cancer research, good care, intelligence and the resources to take advantage of what is available. That might not be enough, but the "defeat" will be on the shoulders of all the doctors, researchers etc. who have failed to cure her disease.   I will not let them off the hook by saying that she is somehow responsible to "fight" for her life.

Posts.Title: Preinvasive breast cancer label may affect treatment choice cp418 ballet12

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2010 07:55PM - edited Jul 12, 2010 08:00PM by riverhorse Thank you so much for your observations.  Since my daughter's diagnosis I have been troubled by the "fighting cancer" metaphor.  The implication is if you fight you can win -- and if you lose it is because you didn't "fight" hard enough.  Why isn't the "fight" between the medical profession and the disease?   From reading this board I have come to think that appropriate treatment, monitoring, adequate resources, proximity to good care etc. are more likely to contribute to a better outcome than "fighting" spirit.  I think that when outcomes are not optimal the fault lies in the failure of the medical profession to find a cure.   It is also astounding that it is almost a given on this board that the patient must take responsibility for finding the best most effective treatment for her own iteration of the disease rather than relying on a medical professional. With all the money poured into research and the political clout of organized groups such as the Susan B. Komen organization it is strange that more progress has not been made towards a cure or at least a more proactive approach for stage IV patients. But I am new to all this so perhaps my observations are way off base.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2013 06:03PM riverhorse wrote: Double mastectomy w/ sentinel node biopsy. Not much pain at all. Five days sick leave total. But I did have some sort of pain meds delivered constantly for a few days. It was in a plastic ball worn at my waist and delivered through some tubing to the affected area. After it was finished in three days or so I needed no further pain meds.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2013 02:21PM riverhorse wrote: I too worked for the federal government and still have my health insurance through the government.  After retiring a federal employee can keep the insurance at the same premium.   My husband is also retired from the Army.  Although we did not elect to use it, Tri-care is available for retired military.   All the time I workd for the feds (20 years) I never heard that one needed to pay union dues to get federal benefits.  Regarding STD -- I really don't know, but I do know that the feds have a sick leave bank that employees can draw from when they have extended absences due to illness.  Maybe the STD is only a union benefit.  You might want to check with the appropriate person in your agency who deals with benefits.   Oh I too am on Aromasin and it is now generic and I do not pay much.
Posts.Title: Short term disability and life ins....so frustrated right now! jennyboog mary625

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2010 06:03PM riverhorse wrote: Non-citizens who have worked and paid into the Social Security system can collect Social Security Disability Insurance benefits when they are disabled. Aliens who are permanent legal residents of the U.S. receive benefits based on the same eligibility criteria as U.S. citizens. Unlike U.S. citizens, non-citizens may be ineligible to receive benefits if they begin to live outside the U.S., Washington D.C. or its territories (Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands and American Samoa). Non-citizens usually must pay withholding taxes on any SSDI received outside the U.S. Although aliens who are permanent, legal residents of the U.S. and its territories can collect the same SSDI benefits as U.S. citizens, many restrictions affect only non-citizens who leave the U.S. These restrictions may also affect benefits paid to their dependents. Whether they can still receive benefits while living abroad, and the amount of tax they must pay, depends on their own country of citizenship as well as the country of residence. Social Security: Disability Benefits Social Security: Your Payments While You are Outside the United States Disability: Connecting the Disability Community to Information and Opportunities Social Security Handbook Social Security: Additional Requirements for Alien Workers- Social Security Protection Act of 2004

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2013 04:02PM riverhorse wrote: I met with a onc at MD Anderson who told me that when an ER+ tumor returns as TN, it is not the same as a tumor that was originally TN.  You should ask your wife's onc if he agrees with that analysis and what the implications are.  I was given to believe that a tumor that has changed from ER+ to TN is not as agressive as a tumor that was originally TN.

Posts.Content: riverhorse wrote: Hello  My daughter was recently diagnosed with BC and spots on the liver.   I have come across a website that has a wealth of information on MBC and thought the wonderful people on this board might benefit from the information it contains.   It is called Breast Cancer Watch and the link is  http://breastcancer.evidencewatch.com/ I have spent a great deal of time trying to understand all the ramifications of this awful disease and how to combat it.  I think this site offers valuable information for all who are dealing with this personally or due to the illness of a loved one. Dx 11/22/2011, ILC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2014 10:18AM - edited Oct 4, 2014 12:10PM by riverhorse Regarding the stats in the journal article -- for each of us the reality of MBC is either 0% or 100%.  No one gets 30% or 70% MBC.   Stats can give us a false sense of security (say 10% chance of MBC) or perhaps unwarranted fear (70% chance of MBC).  But the fact remains that none of the stats are 0% or 100% for any group, even stage 4 (1-2% Get to and remain NED) .  The emphasis must be on a cure.   No one is cured until everyone is cured!!
Posts.Title: Brace yourself, September is slipping, inexorably, to Foctober weesa Blessings2011

Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 03:50PM riverhorse wrote: So interesting.   I had the Mammaprint first -- came back low risk, but -- and this is a big but --"borderline"  So I had the Oncotype, came back 25 intermediate.  I guess the two tests were consistent, but really didn't help me.  And of course that was another 8K for my insurance company for two tests.  The adjuvant on-line reached the same conclusions regarding distant recurrance risk at no charge.   After much agonizing and a second opinion I was left to my own devices to make the decision.  This is one of the many things that is so maddening about BC -- since no one can really tell you what will work, the patient is left to make decisions that with other maladies would be made by the physician. This approach kind of relieves the physician of responsibility for poor outcomes.  As my onc said in discussing my situation, "Its all a crap shoot anyway."  I did not have chemo.
